stories.title: The Bone-Singer's Lament
stories.text: Kess of the Drowned Hollows was no sorcerer—she was a bone-singer, keeper of the old songs that bound stone and root together. When the Rot-King's plague spread through her village, she watched her community blacken with septic rot and knew the old songs would not save them. The Crown sent a priest to offer divine mercy. Kess refused. Instead, she walked into the deep forest where the beast-spirits dwelt, singing the names of the dead in the tongue that predated kingdoms. A wolf-spirit the size of a war-horse emerged from shadow, antlered and terrible. It offered her a bargain: the plague would lift, but Kess's voice would be taken—she would spend her years mute, singing only in dreams. She sang her assent. By dawn, the blackening stopped. The survivors lived. Kess returned to the village silent, her throat burned with ancient magic, and began teaching them the old songs with her hands. Some debts are paid in silence.

stories.title: The Cartographer's Gambit
stories.text: Mardoc the Cartographer had mapped half the Known World but never the Sunken Caverns—supposedly guarded by the Lamia herself. He didn't believe in monsters. He believed in curiosity and clever tongues. When he descended into the pearl-dark waters and found the Lamia coiled around a throne of bone, he didn't draw his sword. Instead, he showed her his maps: blank pages. "The world doesn't know you exist," he said. "In my maps, you will be eternal. Not feared—witnessed." The Lamia, who had spent centuries watched only by the dead, laughed—a sound like breaking glass and singing whales. She let him map her caverns, her gardens of bioluminescent coral, her vault of pearls. In return, he added her portrait to every map he made, her true name inscribed in silver leaf. When Mardoc emerged six months later, his maps had become legend. And in taverns across the world, sailors whispered of the Lamia not as a monster, but as a sovereign—a choice she had never had before.

stories.title: The Thief-Lord's Daughter
stories.text: Silene grew up in the shadow of her father's legend—Kael the Nameless, a shadow-broker who'd stolen secrets for emperors before vanishing into myth. She wanted no part of his shadow-trade. She wanted to forge steel. They offered her a choice: take up her father's trade or watch her master burn. In desperation, Silene stole a shadow from the Collectors themselves—not with sorcery, but with steel and cunning, cutting it from a sleeping thug's heel at midnight. She bound the stolen shadow into her father's old ledger, a ghost-memory of his secrets, and gave it to the Collectors as collateral. "I'm not my father," she told them, "but I learn fast." By dawn, she'd forged her own name into the shadow-broker's network—not as Kael's heir, but as Silene the Bright, a thief who dealt not in darkness but in truth.

stories.title: The Widow's Bargain
stories.text: Lady Thressa was a widow at twenty-three, her husband fallen to rot-plague. The Emperor's alchemist offered her a vial of restoration honey—a elixir that could unmake death itself. The price: her tongue. "So you cannot speak his name again," the alchemist said, "ensuring the magic holds true. Names anchor the living to the world. Remove the name, and the dead may walk free." Thressa drank the honey without hesitation. Her tongue withered to ash. Her husband's sepulcher fractured at midnight, and he stepped forth pale and ravenous—not alive, but undead, sustained by the alchemical force that had stolen her voice. For three nights, she watched him consume the village's livestock, his hunger bottomless. On the fourth dawn, she burned her late husband's portrait and wrote his name in her own blood across his grave. The alchemy shattered. He crumbled. She stood silent, her voice forever gone, knowing she had given the Emperor's alchemist exactly what he'd wanted: proof that the magic worked. And she would tell no one.

stories.title: The Crown-Thief of Ashen Wastes
stories.text: Tory the Redhand led a crew of four across the Scorched Flats toward the Ruins of Old Keth, where a merchant-prince had hidden the Crown of Karesh—not to wear it, but to keep it from the Lich-King's collectors. The curse binding that crown was legend: it compounded with each theft, each decade of possession adding weight and madness. Tory didn't care about curses. She cared about the merchant-prince's promise: one million gold pieces to the crew that brought it to him within the new moon. Her crew included Gareth (a dwarf locksmith who'd worked the Deepvault), Mell (a scout with fae-blood who could see in starlight), and Kovin (a sellsword bound to Tory by oath). They breached the crown-vault using lockpicks forged from meteor-iron, avoided the animate statues through Mell's fae-sight, and seized the crown inside a silk veil—never touching it bare. But at the vault's exit, Gareth weakened. The curse was already seeping into his blood, drawn by proximity. Tory made the choice: she cut Gareth free from his oath, handed him the crown-wrapped bundle, and told him to return to the merchant-prince alone. "Break the curse however you can," she said. "But it's no longer our problem." Gareth limped north with the crown. Tory, Mell, and Kovin vanished into the flats. Sometimes, Tory knew, the best crew knows when to split.

stories.title: The Sea-Debt
stories.text: Captain Nerida of the Vengeful Tide had stolen a pearl from the Lamia's vault twenty years ago—not for gold, but as proof she'd survived the Sunken Caverns. The merfolk had never forgotten. When her crew caught the scent of salt-magic on the wind and tasted brine in the air despite being landlocked, Nerida knew they'd come to collect. She gathered her crew in the hold of her beached ship and told them the truth: the debt was hers alone, and she would not let them suffer for her pride. That night, she sailed alone on a dinghy into the storm the merfolk had summoned. They rose from the black water—sleek and terrible—and offered her a bargain: her crew's service for a season, sailing merfolk-bound ships into the deep, or her own life, slowly drowned. Nerida laughed and dove into the sea before they could choose for her. The merfolk dragged her down, gasping, into their cities of coral and shell. But instead of drowning, she was transformed—her lungs shifted to gills, her eyes widened to see in the crushing dark. They made her a captain of their deep-navy, bound by magic and debt but alive. Every new moon, she surfaces near her old crew's port and leaves a message carved in coral: *Still sailing. Still yours.* They never take it down.

stories.title: The Courtier's Secret
stories.text: Lord Caevan served the Queen as her closest advisor for fifteen years, whispering strategy and policy into her ear. But he was not truly Caevan. He was a fae-born changeling, sworn to a Seelie Court that wanted the kingdom destabilized. Every counsel he gave—every tax he suggested, every alliance he sabotaged—served his hidden masters. The Queen never suspected. Until the kingdom was threatened by the Rot-King's forces, and Caevan felt something crack inside his changeling heart. Chains of magic compelled him to whisper poison into the Queen's ear, to counsel surrender and ruin. Instead, he bit his own tongue nearly in half and tasted blood. The pain broke the fae-compulsion, just barely. In the Queen's private chambers, he confessed everything: his true nature, the Seelie Court's demands, his fifteen years of betrayal. The Queen could have him executed. Instead, she offered him a choice: remain human, live as a man, and help her wage war against the forces that would destroy her realm. Caevan accepted, knowing his fae-life was forfeit. He spent the next year planning campaigns that would drive back the Rot-King's armies and secure the kingdom's future. It was the first honest work he'd ever done.

stories.title: The Forge-Witch's Test
stories.text: Bryn the Dwarven Smith had forged weapons for three kingdoms but never taken a lover—she'd sworn an oath to her craft, believing love would dull her focus. When Ashara the Archer arrived at her forge with a bow in pieces, asking for repair, Bryn felt something shift. Over weeks of working the wood and steel, they spoke. Ashara had lost her partner in the Siege of Blackthorn, had sworn never to attach herself to another. They recognized each other's loneliness. On the night Bryn completed Ashara's bow, she admitted the truth: she'd deliberately delayed the repair, extending their time together. Ashara laughed—a sound like breaking glass—and said she'd deliberately re-damaged the bow to return. They stood close by the forge's heat, the metal around them singing in harmony neither had heard before. The next morning, they chose to leave together, Bryn closing her forge, Ashara setting down her bow. They walked into the mountains to find a place where they could simply be—no oaths, no magic, no forges burning. Just two people who'd chosen each other.

stories.title: The Goblin-King's Mercy
stories.text: Mogrul ruled the goblin warrens beneath the Spire of Blackstone with a fist of iron and a voice like grinding stone. He had conquered the underground kingdoms through cunning and war, had enslaved whole clans, had turned their blood into mortar for his throne. Then the Rot-King's plague seeped down from above, and it made no distinction between goblin and human. The sick piled up in the warrens like cordwood. Mogrul's shamans could not halt it. His warlords fell to blackening fever. In desperation, he sent envoys to the surface—to Aeleth the Veilwright, the hermit wise-woman who dwelt in the Grey Reaches—and offered her a kingdom's ransom if she could cure his people. She would teach his shamans the old songs that could turn back plague-rot, but only if his kingdom became a fellowship of free peoples. Mogrul refused at first. But watching his people burn with fever, he yielded. It took years to rebuild the warrens as a confederation rather than an empire, but the plague lifted. When the Rot-King's forces tried to invade the underground, they found not a kingdom of slaves but a unified network of goblin-nations, stronger than before. Mogrul kept his throne, but he shared it. The wise-woman never returned to the Grey Reaches. Instead, she built a sanctuary in the deepest warren, where goblin and human healers worked side by side.

stories.title: The Starfall Oath
stories.text: Zareth the Astronomer-Prince had spent his life reading the stars, but he'd never truly listened to them until the Violet Conjunction passed across the sky. In that impossible twilight, the stars spoke—not in words, but in certainty and vast sorrow. They were dying. In ten thousand years, they would go dark, and the world would follow into endless night. Unless. Unless someone could master the old magic—the magic that predated gods and kingdoms—and perform the Stellar Rite, a working that would birth new stars from the ashes of the old. No sorcerer living had the knowledge. No grimoire recorded the words. Zareth swore an oath beneath the Conjunction: he would find the Rite, master it, or die trying. He spent the next seven years walking the known world, seeking elders, excavating burial-halls, learning from druids and bone-carvers and fae-touched hermits. In the Singing Catacombs, he found a cave wall inscribed in languages predating humanity itself. He copied them, decoded them, understood. The Rite required a sacrifice—not blood, but memory. The caster would have to give up every moment of joy, every love, every triumph, every small beauty that made life worth living. In exchange, new stars would be born, the cycle would continue, and the world would live. On the night of the next Conjunction, Zareth climbed a mountain and began the working. As he spoke the ancient words, he felt his memories drain away—his first kiss, his mother's laugh, the taste of wine, the color blue—all of it gone, fed to the Rite. When he opened his eyes, the sky was blazing with newborn stars. He wept, though he no longer remembered why. But somewhere, generations hence, the stars would still burn.
